rComments: The woman is a pillar of UofT. When she teaches undergrad classes the size can be intimidating and make you feel like a number, but if you approach her outside of class, she is willing to engage you passionately and give you advice. She has a great sense of humour, treats everyone the same way whether you're a somebody or a nobody. I'm a nobody :P
It was fine.

Very over-rated.  I can't think of a single salient thing I learned in that class.  Best lecture of year was given by the TA! No creativity or effort to meaningfully engage students was put into the class. She is helping to create yet another generation of heartless bureaucrats.  :(

didn't learn anything that i didn't already know. prof is overrated; i have had many better profs at uoft. lectures were boring and a waste of my time.eas a first year course, it is easy but the assignments are kind of irrelevent to what they teach the entire year. only interesting part about this class was some of the readings.

I spent 5 years as an undergrad at McGill and came to U of T for my Master's because of the strong international reputation of its PolSci department.  Janice, alone, serves as representative evidence of the degree to which this program is overrated.  Not unlike her writing, her lectures are not empirically grounded and make no original contribution
Inability to capture the imagination of the student. Poor clarity. Does not clearly state arguments. Overall confusing.
No need to attend lectures, Tutorial and reading will get you an A. Lectures do not teach you anything you dont already know.

I don't know why ppl think she's a great prof. She may be famous but she's not that engaging because she repeats one thing in the slide at least 10x before moving on. I've had way more interesting profs who can present better. Tests are all right, though.

This course is as interesting as it is schizophrenic; inevitably with two professors teaching two different matters that cater to their specialities, they somehow find a meeting point between their respective ranges of knowledge but it is very much a course where you are thrown for a loop at time as to how it all comes together (cohesively?)
Amazing teacher, makes learning worthwhile

Took this course last year. Good prof, but horrible class. Seems like the only purpose the class has is so the profs can talk about what they have done. Also-- the fact that we had to do some project on an NGO and were only marked on a self evaluation was a waste of time.

celebrity prof that everyone seems to have an opinion on. Took POL108 in 2005 and honestly did not learn anything that I did not already know. Aside from the mediocre course material she was definitely a capable lecturer/orator. Diebert is a pothead weeny.

She is okay for a professor.. maybe a little boring but at least she tries to get the class involved. My problem is some of the statements she makes are wrong and she tends to exaggerate statistics. One that was 8000 one week became 80 000 the next.

Brilliant professor! Her perspectives are worth listening to. Although not usaully in lectures; it's because she has conferences. Deibert is equally brilliant. They make a great team. I have a hunch the person below bombed the course.

impossibly, outrageously, deplorably bad. and her little partner dilbert. the two of them . . . the only course i ever dropped at u of t. that's right: losing 800 bucks felt better than sitting through more hours of self-references ('the last time i was in Amman . . . ')
I took this course in 1999 so I don't know if she's still teaching.  Didn't learn a thing in POL108 one of my big disappointments.

Janice Stein is passionate and compassionate. She truly intends to engage each student (of which she does a great job, especially considering the large class sizes!), and to make the world a better, more peaceful, more educated place.
An engaging lecturer and can incorporate class discussions in a class of any size.

An impossibly nice person, Prof. Stein is articulate and knowledgeable about her subject.  That said, in a class that packs Convocation Hall, it's easy to get lost in the crowd (and almost all of us do).  If you need lots of one-on-one time, don't count on it here.

Professor Stein is a brilliant, articulate, and caring person, and I can appreciate this fact a lot more two years after taking her course.  I suggest making the most of your time with her because what she has to say is remarkable!

Stein is a very brilliant prof. She is really interested in the subject matter and that comes across during her lectures. The slides aren't very helpful, mostly just unanswered questions that she poses for discussion. Overall, the class was a good experience.
shes just boring, slow, too old to press space for the slides to go?...anyhow, cant take her lectures ..SO BAD

Prof Stein definately knows her stuff. Her lectures are full of good information but unfortunately they sometimes lack a lot of slides so its hard to get everything down. The way Pol108 is run is very fair. If you expect to see Stein at every lecture tho, think again - in first term she only came to 3 or 4 and Deibert took care of the rest
she is brilliant!
Although her lectures can be dull, she gets to the point and makes things clear!  She is helpful once you leave her lectures, you have a better understanding of the topic!
She may be 'intelligent,' but she's also quite boring, self righteous, and slow.

Professor Stein is a very engaging prof - although there are times when her lectures can get dull and she begins to ask too many rhetorical questions, Stein really tries to spark interest and debate in the class (which she successfully does in a class with 850). She's also a very intelligent woman!!!

Stien is a great speaker, very clear and understanding of the students needs. Understand that she doesn't do any of the marking so if you have a tight TA then good luck. Her exams are fair, and it is a very intersting course. I would reccomend it to all political science students, and for non-poli sci students it will still spark interest.

I thought Stein was an excellent professor.  Although her lectures could get quite dry and long, she made sure she covered all that she possibly could.  She is a great asset to the political science department at U of T and a strong woman at that.

She speaks so damn slowly like we're retarded babies or something. She also has a HUGE ego. I mean, professor of International Relations and she doesn't even know what happened to the americans in Somalia. I think when you're making 6 figures a year, you should be able to rent Black Hawk Down. No?
People who have rated Stein negatively don't know what they are talking about. She is a brilliant, thoughtful and socially conscious professor.

boring, boring boring. she talks and talks and talks... until you want to kill yourself. they lure you with Professor Dilbert (which is the best) and you end up having just 4 lectures with him and the rest with that horrible ****.
Very intelligent, knows what she's talking about, has been there. Cares about her subject and the students and getting involved. Lecture style can be dull and repetitive.
likes to take credit for work done by her younger vassals, skip Stein, get Welch
she's ok i guess, her lecture notes are decent and summarize whats important in this pointless class....dont waste your time with the "required" readings
No Comments
Awful.
You will learn nothing in this class.

she's alright.. boring a bit here and there.  when i asked her a question about a book she wrote, she said she doesn't remember because it's been a long time she wrote it, and that i should just keep on reading it.  not very helpful.
shes on tv all the time because she on a call-service contract (gets $$$) with the cbc to be on call whenever they want her --my dad works there.
Good Prof, I just wounldn't do her.
She certainly knew her stuff, though that is not difficult considering how simple lots of the concepts were. Stein an ok lecturer, but you'll look forward to the days when Deibert is lecturing.
A real hag. Taking her course was just painful, she doesn't know what she's doing.
She is all hype....  Janice is unknowledgeable even relative to students, and attempts to use broad concepts to hide her ignorance...
Interesting course material ... very organized lectures
she's fine...
if she spent less time clicking her shoes and talking about israel and more time talking about GLOBAL issues, maybe, she garner a better rep. narrow-minded and lacking in oral intrigue.
she's a clear speaker... but she does tend to be a lil boring at times. It's hard not to fall asleep in her class...
damn hope you never have to sit through one of her lectures
Very knowlegeable. Listen to her and think on it - there is a reason why she is on TV. Interesting to talk to and is an all around nice person.
borrrrring
No Comments

My God her voice gets so annoying to the point where your ears dont want to take anything in.... your body shivers as she speaks... your mind loses knowledge as she breathes. Suicide is almost a possibility with her... no joke she is that BORING!
No Comments
This lady should have spent more time @ teachers college.
One word "BORING"
No Comments

Extremely boring…Simple minded biased War-Monger. She might be good enough to write books but she is not predestined to be a lecturer. COULD ANY ONE TELL ME WHY SHE IS ON TV? GAAAD!!! THIS LADY IS UNINSPIRING!
Extremely well read. Quite boring and biased. Sometimes her voice starts to crack and she sounds like she's dying. She's like the emperor from The Dark Crystal.
good prof
No Comments
Needs to pay more attention to her students, and less to her television/pundit career.
Very clear, brilliant woman, courageous views, but incredibly biased
She is brilliant, but seems  biased on TV SHOWS on some ISSUES!
No Comments
the woman is brilliant. nuff said.
